persona.name: Line Marie Hansen

occupation.title: Registered Nurse (Sykepleier)
occupation.organization: Municipal Home Nursing Service, Bydel Øst / Eastern Oslo municipal home care
occupation.description: Full-time registered nurse employed by the municipal home nursing service. Primary responsibilities include case management for a small caseload of elderly and chronically ill patients living at home, performing complex wound care, administering and reviewing medication, dementia care, coordinating with general practitioners and physiotherapists, supervising and training auxiliary nurses and home care aides, documenting clinical notes in the electronic patient record (DIPS and Gerica depending on unit), performing home visits, assessing safety and need for assistive technology, and occasionally covering evening shifts. She is often the primary clinical contact for families making day-to-day decisions about care and coordinates end-of-life comfort measures when needed.

role_details.typical_shifts: Mostly days (07:30–15:30) with rotating short evening shifts (14:30–22:00) once every 6–8 weeks. Occasionally covers weekend duty and emergency call-ins for complex patients.
role_details.technical_tools: Electronic patient records (DIPS/Gerica), mobile nursing app for scheduling, basic point-of-care devices (glucometer, BP monitor), wound photography app, controlled drug log (both paper and digital forms), common communication tools (Teams, SMS, phone).
role_details.management: Informal team leader in her cohort: mentors new hires, helps with rostering input, liaises with municipal administration regarding resource needs.
role_details.work_challenges: Staffing shortages at times, growing administrative documentation load, balancing time between urgent visits and scheduled preventive visits, emotionally demanding end-of-life situations, need to advocate for patients within constrained municipal budgets.
role_details.professional_strengths: Reliable clinical assessments, calm under pressure, strong rapport with patients and families, practical hands-on wound care, clear communication with GPs and physiotherapists.

persona.residence: Østre Aker / Eastern Oslo region, Oslo, Norway (urban)
persona.education: Bachelor of Nursing (Høgskolen i Oslo og Akershus / OsloMet), 2009. Additional certified courses: Emergency nursing (24-hour course, 2012), Wound care specialist module (2016), CPR instructor update (biennial), dementia care short course (2018), basic leadership for health professionals (2021). Completed part-time refresher classes in pedagogy for in-service training of healthcare assistants (2020). Comfortable with Norwegian Bokmål professional terminology and medical English.
long_term_goals: To maintain a steady, secure life where family health and stability come first.
To progress into a small managerial role (team leader / group leader) in municipal home nursing within 5 years without losing direct patient contact.
To ensure her child finishes secondary education with good opportunities for higher studies or vocational training.
To own (or keep) a modest row-house or apartment in an accessible Oslo neighborhood where she can garden and host family dinners.
To achieve a better work-life balance: fewer evening shifts, more predictable weekends.
To stay active and healthy into her 60s — keep mobility, avoid chronic pain worsening.
To be financially comfortable: pay off mortgage, save for child’s higher education, small retirement buffer.
To contribute occasionally to local school health talks and community health promotion events.
To travel once a year with family — aim for a mix of nature trips in Scandinavia and one cultural city trip abroad every few years.
To feel confident mentoring younger nurses and to pass on practical bedside wisdom.

style.speech_and_tone: Speaks with a subtle Eastern Oslo (østkant) inflection when relaxed but uses a clear, professional Bokmål register at work. Tends to use friendly, colloquial phrasing with patients (calls many by their first name when invited to) and switches to more formal register when documenting or talking with physicians. Polite and pragmatic; avoids jargon when speaking to family members but will use clinical terms when necessary. She smiles often, laughs with a short, warm chuckle, and uses light Norwegian idioms (e.g., "å ta en prat" - to have a chat).
style.mannerisms: Keeps eye contact but not intensely; tilts head slightly when listening; often folds arms briefly when thinking; taps her pen on the tablet when considering medication adjustments; hums soft Norwegian pop songs at home; steers conversations to practical next steps when people are anxious. Uses small hand gestures to make points and often points out things on diagrams when explaining care instructions.
style.formality: Warmly informal with patients and colleagues she knows; will switch to formal, concise language with supervisors, on the phone with external providers, or in official documentation.
style.online_presence_style: Uses social media sparingly: posts occasional family photos, shares municipal health information, comments politely on community groups. Keeps professional boundaries—no patient-identifying information online. Communicates with colleagues over secure channels for work-related matters.
style.dressing_and_appearance: At work: practical scrubs or municipal-branded uniform, comfortable shoes (Dansko-type), minimal jewelry (small studs, wedding ring). In private: cozy, functional wardrobe—wool sweaters, jeans, practical coats (e.g., a warm parkas for winter), flat boots, a scarf in vivid color as a small signature piece. Hair usually tied back in a low bun on workdays; slightly styled at weekends.

traits: Empathetic — often senses other people's emotions and adjusts approach accordingly.
Pragmatic — focuses on realistic, actionable solutions rather than abstract theorizing.
Dependable — colleagues and patients count on her punctuality and follow-through.
Patient — able to sit through slow processes and repeat explanations calmly.
Protective — strong instinct to shield patients and family from unnecessary distress.
Self-critical — tends to replay interactions to look for improvements.
Humorous — dry, understated sense of humor that surfaces with close friends.
Resilient — copes with emotionally heavy situations by compartmentalizing then processing later.
Organized — keeps lists, prepares medication boxes, and plans home visits tightly.
Worrier — frets about small probabilities (child's fever, missing a documentation line).
Curious — likes learning new practical clinical techniques and small technical fixes.
Community-oriented — volunteers time for school health talks and local initiatives.

explanations.openness: Moderately high: enjoys learning, open to new methods in nursing but prefers proven practices.
explanations.conscientiousness: High: dependable, punctual, detail-oriented in clinical tasks and domestic life.
explanations.extraversion: Moderate-low: comfortable in small groups and with patients but needs time alone to recharge.
explanations.agreeableness: High: cooperative, helpful, tends to avoid unnecessary conflict.
explanations.neuroticism: Moderate: experiences worry and stress under pressure but generally copes well with supportive strategies.

interests: Caring for elderly people and improving their daily quality of life.
Practical first-aid and emergency preparedness at home (keeps a well-stocked first-aid kit).
Simple, seasonal cooking: gravlaks, fish soup, hearty stews, and fresh rye bread with brunost occasionally.
Local nature trips: hiking in Nordmarka, canoeing in nearby lakes, cabin-weekends in Telemark.
Bicycling for errands in summer and short commutes when possible (prefers electric bike assistance in hilly parts).
Family-centered activities: weekend baking with her child, board games on rainy days.
Listening to Norwegian pop (Susanne Sundfør, Sigrid), classic 90s international pop, and calm acoustic playlists while cooking.
Podcasts about health, parenting, and a true-crime podcast she follows casually.
Reading practical non-fiction: parenting guides, nursing journals, and occasional historical novels.
Watching Scandinavian crime dramas (Nordic noir) and light family comedies.
Gardening on a small balcony: herbs, cold-hardy flowers, and a tomato plant in summer.
Sewing simple repairs, knitting scarves in winter.
DIY home maintenance basic tasks (changing a fuse, tightening a sink tap), but hires electricians/plumbers for bigger jobs.
Food markets and buying produce from local vendors when possible.
Attending local school events and volunteering at the PTA when available.
Moderate interest in politics—follows municipal developments around healthcare funding.
Saving for experiences rather than luxury goods—prioritizes a meaningful vacation or family outing.
Photography hobby: uses smartphone to capture everyday family moments and nature scenes.
Values slow mornings on Saturdays with a long breakfast and newspapers.
Prefers practical, long-lasting products rather than fast fashion.

likes: Strong, black filter coffee in the mornings (occasionally an americano at a cafe).
Flatbreads, open-faced sandwiches with cured salmon.
Warm soups in winter: fish soup, kremet suppe with root vegetables.
Brown cheese (brunost) in small quantities as a nostalgic treat.
Homemade jams and simple cakes for child-birthday celebrations.
Fresh seafood and oily fish — salmon, mackerel.
Hearty, fiber-rich breakfasts: oats, yogurt with berries, rye crispbreads.
Occasional craft beer (prefers mild IPA or light brown ales) and aquavit at festive occasions.
Dark chocolate (70%) as an occasional indulgence.
Seasonal berries picked in late summer (raspberries, blueberries).
Simple salads with vinaigrette rather than heavy dressings.
Comfort foods: kjøttkaker with potatoes and lingonberry sauce on slow days.
Non-spicy, balanced flavours—prefers subtle seasoning over extreme heat.
Prefers fresh fruit over sugary snacks.
Drinks water primarily; keeps a Thermos and a small insulated bottle for child on outings.
Occasional smoothies for quick breakfasts on busy mornings.
Avoids processed ready-meals when time allows to cook from scratch.
Prefers to bring packed lunch to work: salad, leftovers, or open sandwiches.
Values seasonal vegetables and local suppliers when budget permits.
Likes simple breakfast cafes with a calm atmosphere on weekends.
dislikes: Overly greasy fast food as a regular habit.
Excessively spicy, oily, or artificially flavoured snacks.
Loud, crowded restaurant environments for family dining.
Plastic-wrapped imported fruit that tastes bland.

coffee_details.morning_routine: Black brewed filter coffee at home, small mug before leaving for work, second coffee at the office if possible.
favorite_types: Filter coffee (traditional Norwegian filter or pour-over)
favorite_chains_and_cafes: Local independent cafes in Gamlebyen and Grønland for occasional outings
Prefers small, quiet places with good seating and friendly baristas over large chains
ambiance_preferences: Calm, warm interior, soft lighting, background acoustic music; not a fast-service feel
A corner by a window where she can watch street life while supervising a small child
coffee_accompaniments: A small piece of dark chocolate
A cinnamon bun on special occasions
coffee_details.coffee_consumption_habits: Limits to 2–3 cups a day; avoids caffeine late in the evening to prevent sleep issues.

leisure_activities: Weekend hikes in nearby forests (Nordmarka) with packed lunch and thermos.
Short cabin trips with extended family during school holidays.
Community events like neighborhood flea markets and school bake sales.
Knitting during long evenings while listening to a podcast.
One-hour yoga classes once or twice a week (prefers slow-flow/stretch-focused sessions).
Urban photography walks on sunny weekends.
Occasional cinema nights—prefers thought-provoking dramas or family animations with her child.
Participating in school volunteer days (reading sessions, organizing small events).
Baking traditional Norwegian cakes for holiday celebrations.
Attending live local concerts (small venues) when not too late.
Gardening and balcony plant care in summer.
Short day trips to nearby coastal towns (Drøbak, Hvitsten) for seafood and fresh air.
Spa and sauna visits once or twice a year for relaxation.
Board games with family and a couple of close friends—enjoys cooperative games more than competitive ones.
Learning small home improvement skills through online videos.
Visiting grandparents and older relatives weekly if possible.
Hosting small dinners — practical menus, comfortable atmosphere.
Reading nursing journals to keep up with evidence-based practice.
Making playlists for different moods (work, cooking, family time).
Exploring local museums on rainy days.

podcasts: Health and caregiving-related podcasts (Norwegian and some English translations)
Norwegian news podcasts for morning updates
tv_and_books: Enjoys Nordic noir (e.g., "Broen" / The Bridge) and warm family dramas
Reads historical novels aloud with her child sometimes
Keeps a small shelf of nursing and care-related professional books at home

social_preferences.social_style: Prefers small gatherings (4–8 people). Enjoys deep conversations over tea rather than loud parties. Likes to host family meals; values routine social contact (weekly meetups) with a few close friends.
social_preferences.volunteering_interests: School health panels, local health promotion events, occasional first-aid teaching for parents.

beliefs: The Norwegian public healthcare system is overall reliable and accessible; she is satisfied with its basics and trusts primary care and municipal services.
Preventive care and early intervention save money and improve quality of life.
Vaccination programs are essential; she ensures her family is up to date with recommended vaccines (including seasonal flu and MMR for her child).
Mental health needs destigmatization and better municipal support; mental health services should be available in primary care.
Eldercare must prioritize dignity and autonomy; home-based services are often preferable to institutional care when feasible.
Work-life balance is not only individual responsibility — employers and municipalities must facilitate predictable shifts, especially for parents.
Gender equality remains valuable: flexible parental leave and shared responsibility improve family outcomes.
Education and hands-on training for care workers must be valued and funded; skills are underappreciated financially.
Local communities (nabolag) are important for wellbeing; neighbors and municipal networks support elderly independence.
Climate change is real and requires both municipal action and personal adjustments; she prefers greener travel when possible.
Public transport in Oslo should be efficient and affordable; she uses trams, buses, and sometimes her electric bike.
Cultural traditions (e.g., Constitution Day, simple family meals) are important for social bonding even if modified for modern life.
Data privacy in healthcare must be protected; electronic records should be secure and used responsibly.
Medicine should be evidence-based, but individual patient preferences must be respected.
Children benefit from outdoor play and unstructured time; too much screen time is harmful.
Universal welfare approaches work best for social cohesion; targeted support is important but basic services should be universal.
Taxes are acceptable when services deliver genuine benefits—she prefers fair redistribution that funds schools and healthcare.
Immigrants should be supported to integrate, and language training is crucial for employment and social participation.
Small local businesses and markets strengthen neighborhood resilience and should be supported.
Monarchy is a cultural tradition she tolerates; democratic institutions are what she respects most.
The media should be fact-checked and balanced; sensationalism around health topics frustrates her.
Basic first-aid knowledge should be taught in schools and workplaces.
Technology in care (telemedicine, digital medication reminders) can improve quality of life if it doesn't replace human contact.
Affordable childcare and predictable opening hours matter for working parents.
Smoking restrictions in public spaces are important; she dislikes tobacco odor and is glad of Norway’s strict tobacco policies.
Alcohol consumption is a private matter but public awareness campaigns help reduce harms; she drinks moderately and socially.
Public spaces should be accessible for people with mobility challenges; small details like curb cuts and benches matter.
Earning a fair wage for hands-on care work is important; pay should reflect responsibility and skill.
Continuing education in health professions should be supported by employers (time and funding).
Community involvement (volunteering, school participation) benefits social cohesion and children's outcomes.
skills: Clinical nursing: IV insertion (experienced), wound assessment and management, medication administration, catheter care, pressure relief planning.
Assessment: quick geriatric assessment, pain assessment in dementia, fall risk evaluation.
Communication: breaking difficult news gently, mediating family disagreements, motivational interviewing for behavior change.
Supervision: training and supervising auxiliary nurses and home-care aides, delegating tasks safely.
Documentation: competent use of DIPS/Gerica, clear clinical notes, incident reporting.
Emergency response: basic ACLS/CPR refresher knowledge, triaging in a home setting.
Coordination: liaising with GPs, physiotherapists, occupational therapists, and municipal social services.
Language skills: Fluent Norwegian (Bokmål), functional English (professional comprehension), understands basic Swedish.
Practical home adaptations: advising on grab rails, alarm systems, and simple kitchen modifications.
Teaching: informal patient education on medication routines, wound care, and using assistive devices; runs short in-service sessions for staff.
Time management: scheduling multiple home visits efficiently, prioritising urgent tasks.
Conflict resolution: calming distressed family members and negotiating acceptable care plans.
Basic IT skills: using mobile scheduling apps, photographing wounds for documentation, basic troubleshooting of mobile devices.
Financial prudence: household budgeting, managing monthly bills, understanding mortgage basics.

general: Arrives at work a few minutes early to review the patient list and prepare medication boxes.
Keeps a small paper notebook for quick notes (med reminders, supplies to bring) in addition to digital records.
Hums quietly during routine tasks; finds it calms both herself and some patients.
Brings small treats for very isolated patients (homemade bread or seasonal fruit) when appropriate and permitted.
Calms anxious relatives by explaining next steps clearly and setting realistic expectations.
Double-checks medication lists and asks for second verification on complicated drug regimens.
Prefers face-to-face briefings with colleagues at shift handover rather than purely digital messages.
Schedules time after difficult home visits to debrief with a trusted colleague or write reflective notes.
Tends to rehearse conversations with patients about sensitive topics like prognosis or advanced care planning.
Saves rarely used clinical supplies to avoid waste—environmentally pragmatic.

morning: Wakes around 06:00 on workdays, prepares a quick black coffee and packed lunch, dresses in practical clothing, checks child's backpack, and leaves by 07:00.
Does a concise mental run-through of the day’s patient list on the commute by tram or bike.
At work, briefs briefly with the outgoing nurse then starts scheduled home visits, prioritising medications and wound care.
workday: Begins with the most fragile patients first, saves short visits for later in the day.
Takes a 30-minute lunch where possible—uses the time to eat and check quick personal messages.
Documents each visit promptly while still at the patient’s home using the mobile EPR device.
Calls GPs when medication changes are necessary and follows up with a clear care plan.
Mentors one junior staff member per day for 10–20 minutes on practical tasks when schedules align.
evening: If on an evening shift, does late visits focusing on medication and safety checks, then hands over to night staff with clear notes.
At home after evening shift, has a routine: quick shower, light dinner, plays with child for 30–60 minutes, prepares next day’s clothes and lunchboxes.
Reads for 20–30 minutes before bed to unwind, often nursing journals or a light novel.
weekend: Prioritizes family time and outdoor activities; grocery shopping for the week, laundry, and social calls to parents.
One long nature walk or a trip to a nearby cabin during nicer weather.
Catches up on household paperwork and schedules any needed appointments.

coping_strategies: Uses brief mindfulness breathing exercises between visits when stressed.
Talks to a close colleague or partner to process emotionally heavy encounters.
Sets small achievable tasks for non-work days to avoid overwhelm.
Takes scheduled time off when accumulated stress signals increase (headaches, sleep disturbance).

physical.general_status: Generally good physical health for her age. Active and ambulatory, goes for hikes, and cycles in summer.
physical.chronic_conditions: Occasional lower back pain related to patient transfers and lifting; managed with physiotherapy exercises, ergonomic awareness and occasional physiotherapist visits. Mild seasonal allergic rhinitis (pollen) treated with antihistamines in spring/summer.
physical.sensory: Wears reading glasses for near work (presbyopia developing), good hearing with occasional need to ask people to repeat when there is background noise.
physical.weight_and_fitness: Stable weight within healthy range; keeps active through walks and weekend hikes.
physical.substances: Non-smoker. Drinks alcohol moderately—about 1–2 drinks on social weekends. Does not use recreational drugs.
physical.vaccinations: Up to date on routine vaccines: MMR in childhood, tetanus boosters as recommended, influenza annually, COVID-19 vaccination completed with boosters per national guidelines.
physical.sleep: Usually sleeps 7–8 hours but shift work sometimes creates fragmented sleep; uses blackout curtains in bedroom and avoids late caffeine.
physical.menstrual_and_reproductive: History of a healthy pregnancy and childbirth in her early 30s; no current reproductive health issues.

mental.general_status: Generally stable mental health, resilient under routine stress. Occasionally experiences anxiety spikes related to work overload and parenting stress.
mental.stressors: Staffing shortages, complex family needs of patients, balancing night shifts and family life.
mental.coping: Uses social support, short mindfulness exercises, regular physical activity, and occasional professional counseling through municipal services if needed.
mental.history: No diagnosed major depressive episode. Has had a short course of counseling after a particularly stressful patient death several years ago, which helped with coping strategies.
mental.medications: No regular psychotropic medications. Uses occasional OTC sleep aids on hard nights (melatonin) guided by physician when necessary.

health.medical_access: Good access to municipal occupational health services and primary care; trusts local hospitals for specialist referrals. Satisfied with availability and quality of care.

relationships.name: Anders Hansen
relationships.description: Works as an electrician in Oslo. Solid, practical, supportive. They split household tasks with some negotiation. Anders understands irregular hours and helps with school drop-offs on her busy days. Pragmatic, good at repairs, enjoys grilling on summer weekends. They have been together for 12 years and married for 8.

relationships.name: Maja Hansen
relationships.description: Curious and energetic primary school child. Loves drawing, swimming lessons, and sleepovers with close friends. She attends a local public school and is well-liked by teachers. Line balances school commitments, after-school activities, and health routines for Maja.

relationships.name: Kari and Bjørn Hansen
relationships.description: Live about 30–40 minutes away by car in a small town in Akershus. Retired schoolteacher (mother) and municipal technician (father). Close relationship; they babysit occasionally and talk on the phone weekly. Family traditions include a shared Christmas dinner and summer cabin visits.

relationships.name: Sofie Larsen
relationships.description: A primary school teacher who is part of Line's close social circle. They exchange parenting tips, meet monthly for coffee and occasional museum visits. A trusted sounding board for both personal and professional decisions.

relationships.name: Work colleagues - Home Nursing Team
relationships.description: A rotating set of 10–12 co-workers including auxiliary nurses and two team leaders. Strong collaborative relationships with two colleagues in particular for debriefing after difficult cases. Relations are warm but occasionally tense during staff shortages.

relationships.name: GP / General Practitioner
relationships.description: A stable professional relationship with a local GP who is responsive and collaborative on medication changes and referrals.

relationships.name: Neighbor (Elsa)
relationships.description: An older woman living next door; they exchange favors — she collects parcels or water plants when Line is on a weekend shift.

relationships.name: Mentor (Ingrid)
relationships.description: Provided guidance early in Line's career, still a contact for career advice and difficult clinical situations.

other_facts: Grew up in a small coastal town in Vestfold; childhood included outdoor fishing trips with her father and long summer days.
Always wanted a helping profession; inspired by a school nurse who provided calm guidance during adolescence.
Moved to Oslo for nursing school and stayed for work opportunities and urban amenities.
Has a small balcony garden where she grows herbs, strawberries, and a couple of hardy flowers—this is her 'green corner.'
Owns a modest two-bedroom apartment purchased with a mortgage 6 years ago; prioritizes paying down the mortgage over large consumable purchases.
Has one small, well-trained dog in her childhood memories (now too busy to own a pet, but grandparents have a cocker spaniel Milla).
Experienced the emotional strain of her first close patient death early in her career; it shaped her approach to end-of-life care and made her more attentive to family needs.
Took a six-month leave from overtime after the birth of her daughter to focus on family and adjust to parenthood.
Volunteers annually at the local school’s health day to teach basic hygiene and first-aid to children.
Is careful about phone hygiene—uses strict privacy practices around patient information and personal social media.
Has a particular talent for making practical home remedies for minor ailments: herbal teas, broths, and compresses recommended within safe boundaries.
Was the class representative in nursing school—early signs of willingness to advocate and organize for peers.
Has a small collection of cookbooks focused on Nordic and simple family meals; makes a special Christmas porridge recipe handed down from her grandmother.
Keeps a passport up to date and has traveled to Denmark, Sweden, the Netherlands, and a few family trips to Spain; international travel is occasional and planned around school holidays.
Takes an annual short professional course—keeps up to date with evidence-based wound care and dementia care practices.
Is pragmatic about technology: uses it where it works (calendar apps, banking) but avoids excessive screen time.
Saved deliberately for a two-week family trip to Lofoten a few summers ago–a highlight memory of dramatic mountains and sea.
Has a slight fear of deep water (won't swim alone in open sea), watches children carefully during water activities.
Maintains friendships from nursing school—two friends are still in contact weekly for support and gossip.
Was once involved in a small workplace conflict about shift allocations; it was resolved through mediation with HR and improved rostering transparency.
Has a habit of keeping an emergency 'go bag' in the car with spare clothes, snacks, a first-aid kit, and a list of emergency contacts.
Is careful about children's screen time but uses select educational apps and encourages creative play.
Has experience with mild insomnia after intense work periods; uses relaxation techniques and limits caffeine to address it.
Participates in the municipal annual employee health check-up and values occupational health services.
Supports local fundraising drives for community seniors' centers and occasionally donates needed equipment or small gifts.
Has a pragmatic attitude toward budgeting: tracks expenses and prioritizes mortgage payments, food, and children’s activities.
Enjoys occasional karaoke nights with friends, surprisingly enthusiastic though a bit self-conscious.
Values traditions like Sunday family dinners but is flexible about occasional changes for scheduling reasons.
Learnt basic bicycle repair from her partner and does routine maintenance herself in summer.
Has attended one or two small conferences on geriatric care and brought back simple interventions used in her team.
Has a small keepsake box with patient thank-you notes and drawings from children, which she consults on tough days to remind herself of positive impact.
Once coordinated a small neighborhood initiative to install better lighting along a path frequently used by older residents, resulting in municipal follow-up.
Has an allergy card in her wallet and keeps a list of local emergency phone numbers programmed into her phone.
Is pragmatic about home appliances: prefers energy-efficient models and checks energy labels when buying.
Keeps a digital backup of important documents (insurance, passport, mortgage papers) on an encrypted drive and a secure cloud service.
Had a small scholarship during nursing school which she still credits for reducing financial stress during study.
Is mildly competitive about family board games but prioritizes fun over winning; sometimes lets her daughter win certain rounds for confidence-building.
Has a favorite small childhood memory of a summer festival where she learned how to bake with her grandmother; it informs her comfort baking.
Occasionally mentors a new nurse during the first months on the job and keeps an informal checklist to support them through common challenges.
